comments.message: LOVE this idea!  Isn't there research that shows people have many years of immunity after they survive an exposure?  I thought of this and you will see it on my post "21 day quarantine" but I like the idea of a database and believe that it may also help in people's trust of the healthcare workers.  If they have HAD ebola then they will be trusted.  See my post...Dr. Delise Dickard.

I really don't know anything about blood-but it totally makes sense.I took an anatomy class this summer- and just like any other disease or virus your body builds antibodies against it- so blood with that content should be able to cure it. (or fight against it)Now...if this is true- how can you send it to the masses? Previously infected blood and transport to those who need it. You could design around this. Looked it up and found this:http://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2014/10/14/the-decades-old-treatment-that-may-save-a-young-dallas-nurse-infected-with-ebola/

description: From reading the Science Insider article, the World Health Organization (WHO) is testing whether or not injecting people who are infected with Ebola with the blood of someone who has had Ebola and survived will help cure it. They are testing this based on research that dates from the late 1970's. I think that if we create a database of everyone who we know has had Ebola and survived it, we than can access the database and ask the people in the database if they would be willing to donate blood to try and save lives. In the database we would have all possible information on the donor, ex. Possible diseases they have, sicknesses, blood borne pathogens, and as much data about their well-being as possible.
summary: This idea is for those who are either infected with  Ebola, deal with people infected with Ebola, or care about people who are infected.
title: Ebola outbreak, and a possible cure for it.
